questions.question: Where did Sue and Johnsy live?

options.text: In a rich part of New York
In a colony of struggling artists in New York

questions.answer: In a colony of struggling artists in New York

questions.question: What illness did Johnsy suffer from?
questions.answer: Pneumonia

questions.question: What chance of recovery did the doctor give Johnsy?
questions.answer: One chance in ten

questions.question: What was Johnsy counting while looking out of the window?
questions.answer: Ivy leaves

questions.question: What did Johnsy believe about the falling leaves?

options.text: She would die when the last leaf fell

questions.answer: She would die when the last leaf fell

questions.answer: An old unsuccessful painter

questions.question: Why did Sue call Behrman to the flat?

options.text: To be a model for her painting

questions.answer: To be a model for her painting

questions.question: What was Behrman’s dream?
questions.answer: To paint a masterpiece

questions.question: What happened during the stormy night?

options.text: The last leaf remained on the wall

options.text: She felt hopeful and wanted to live

questions.answer: She felt hopeful and wanted to live

questions.question: What did Johnsy say about wanting to die?
questions.answer: It is sinful

questions.question: What did Johnsy wish to paint one day?
questions.answer: The Bay of Naples

questions.question: What happened to Behrman after that night?
questions.answer: He fell ill with pneumonia

questions.answer: Scattered brushes and a palette

questions.question: What colour was the painted leaf near the stem?
questions.answer: Dark green

questions.answer: Behrman

questions.question: What was Behrman’s masterpiece?
questions.answer: The painted ivy leaf

questions.question: Why did the leaf never flutter?
questions.answer: It was a painting

questions.question: What quality of Behrman is shown in the story?
questions.answer: Sacrifice and kindness

questions.question: Who wrote 'The Last Leaf'?
questions.answer: O. Henry

questions.question: Why did Johnsy lose her will to live?

options.text: She believed she would die when the last ivy leaf fell

questions.answer: She believed she would die when the last ivy leaf fell

questions.answer: Autumn

options.text: Looking out of the window and counting leaves

questions.question: How many leaves were left when Sue first noticed Johnsy counting?
questions.answer: Six

questions.answer: He was shocked and angry

questions.question: What weather condition is mentioned during the night of Behrman’s act?
questions.answer: Cold rain mixed with snow

options.text: It did not fall even in storm

questions.answer: It did not fall even in storm

questions.question: What made Johnsy realise her mistake?

options.text: The last leaf staying on the wall

questions.answer: The last leaf staying on the wall

questions.question: What did Johnsy call her desire to die?
questions.answer: A sin

questions.question: What did Johnsy ask for after regaining hope?
questions.answer: Broth and milk

questions.question: Where was Behrman found after the stormy night?

options.text: In his room, wet and helpless

questions.answer: In his room, wet and helpless

questions.question: Which colours were mixed on Behrman’s palette?
questions.answer: Green and yellow

questions.question: What was Behrman wearing when he was found?
questions.answer: Very wet clothes and shoes

questions.question: How long after that night did Behrman die?
questions.answer: Two days later

options.text: It was painted on the wall

questions.question: What did Behrman always talk about?
questions.answer: Painting a masterpiece

options.text: She had lost her desire to live

questions.answer: She had lost her desire to live

questions.question: What was the ivy vine described as?
questions.answer: Old, gnarled and decayed

questions.question: What did Sue close when Behrman came upstairs?
questions.answer: The window

questions.question: Which part of the leaf was dark green?
questions.answer: Near the stem

questions.question: What did Sue want Johnsy to do while she worked?
questions.answer: Keep her eyes closed

questions.question: What feeling became loose in Johnsy when she was ready to die?

options.text: Ties of friendship and earthly things

questions.answer: Ties of friendship and earthly things

questions.question: What did Johnsy hope to paint someday?
questions.answer: The Bay of Naples

questions.question: Who found Behrman helpless in his room?
questions.answer: The sweeper

questions.question: What did Behrman serve as for young artists?
questions.answer: A model

questions.question: What did Sue think had made Johnsy’s mind weak?
questions.answer: Fever

questions.question: What did Behrman say he would paint someday?
questions.answer: A masterpiece

questions.question: What did Sue notice about Johnsy’s eyes in the morning?

options.text: They were dull and wide open

questions.answer: They were dull and wide open

questions.question: What did Johnsy prepare herself for when she thought the leaf would fall?
questions.answer: The last journey of life

questions.question: What lesson does the story finally teach?
questions.answer: Selfless love can save lives

questions.question: What is the title of the story?
questions.answer: The Last Leaf.

questions.question: Who is the author of 'The Last Leaf'?
questions.answer: O. Henry.

questions.question: Where does the story take place?
questions.answer: In a poorer part of New York, in an artists' colony.

questions.question: Who are the main characters?
questions.answer: Sue, Johnsy, and Old Behrman.

questions.question: What illness does Johnsy suffer from?
questions.answer: Pneumonia.

questions.question: What did the doctor tell Sue about Johnsy's chances?
questions.answer: She had one chance in ten, and that chance depended on her will to live.

questions.question: What false belief does Johnsy have?
questions.answer: She believes that when the last ivy leaf falls, she will die.

questions.question: What does Johnsy count outside her window?
questions.answer: The falling leaves of an old ivy vine.

questions.question: How many leaves are left when Johnsy first starts counting?
questions.answer: Six.

questions.question: What does Sue do for a living?
questions.answer: She is a struggling artist.

questions.question: Why does Sue call Old Behrman to their flat?
questions.answer: To be her model for an old man she is drawing.

questions.question: Who is Old Behrman?
questions.answer: An old, unsuccessful painter who lives downstairs and serves as a model.

questions.question: What is Behrman's dream?
questions.answer: To paint a masterpiece someday.

questions.question: How does Behrman react to Johnsy's fancy?
questions.answer: He is shocked and calls it idiotic.

questions.question: What happens on the night of the storm?
questions.answer: Behrman goes out in the cold rain and snow to paint a leaf on the wall.

questions.question: What do Sue and Johnsy see outside the window the next morning?
questions.answer: One last ivy leaf still clinging to the vine.

questions.question: Why does Johnsy think the leaf will fall?
questions.answer: Because of the fierce wind and rain throughout the night.

questions.question: What change comes over Johnsy the next day?
questions.answer: She regains her will to live, feels guilty for wanting to die, and starts eating.

questions.question: What does Johnsy say is a sin?
questions.answer: To want to die.

questions.question: What happens to Behrman?
questions.answer: He catches pneumonia from being out in the storm and dies in the hospital.

questions.question: What is discovered about the last leaf?
questions.answer: It was painted by Behrman on the wall; it was not a real leaf.

questions.question: What is Behrman's masterpiece?
questions.answer: The painted ivy leaf that saved Johnsy's life.

questions.question: Who saved Johnsy's life and how?
questions.answer: Old Behrman saved her life by painting a leaf on the wall, giving her hope.

questions.question: What is the theme of the story?
questions.answer: Hope, sacrifice, friendship, and the will to live.

questions.question: What is a homophone?
questions.answer: Words that sound the same but differ in spelling and meaning.

questions.question: What is a homograph?
questions.answer: Words that have the same spelling and pronunciation but different meanings in different contexts.

questions.question: Give an example of a homograph from the story.
questions.answer: Well (healthy) and well (water source).

questions.question: What does 'ivy vine' mean?
questions.answer: A strong creeper with green leaves and yellow berries.

questions.question: What does 'gnarled' mean?
questions.answer: Twisted, knotted.

questions.question: What is broth?
questions.answer: A hot soup.

questions.question: What does 'wielded the brush' mean?
questions.answer: Painted skillfully.

questions.question: What is a masterpiece?
questions.answer: An exceptionally beautiful or outstanding work of art.

questions.question: What does 'fancy' mean in the story?
questions.answer: Imagination or false belief.

questions.question: What does 'mingled' mean?
questions.answer: Mixed together.

questions.question: What does 'tinted' mean?
questions.answer: Slightly colored.

questions.question: What is twilight?
questions.answer: The time soon after sunset but before it is completely dark.

questions.question: What does 'fluttered' mean?
questions.answer: Moved with a light, irregular shaking motion.

questions.question: What is the main problem in the story?
questions.answer: Johnsy has lost her will to live and believes she will die when the last leaf falls.

questions.question: What attempts are made to solve the problem?
questions.answer: Sue tries to care for her and cheer her up; Behrman paints the leaf to give her hope.

questions.question: What is the climax of the story?
questions.answer: When Johnsy sees the leaf still there and regains her will to live.

questions.question: How is the problem solved?
questions.answer: Behrman's sacrifice gives Johnsy hope, and she decides to live.

questions.question: What is the end of the story?
questions.answer: Johnsy recovers, but Behrman dies from pneumonia after painting the leaf.

questions.question: Are Sue and Johnsy close friends?
questions.answer: Yes.

questions.question: Is Sue rich?
questions.answer: No, she is a struggling artist.

questions.question: Is Johnsy hopeful at the beginning?
questions.answer: No, she has given up hope.

questions.question: Is Behrman hard-hearted?
questions.answer: No, he is kind and sacrifices himself for Johnsy.

questions.question: Does the real last leaf fall?
questions.answer: Yes, it fell during the storm.

questions.question: Does Johnsy realize her mistake?
questions.answer: Yes, she calls herself wicked and decides to live.

questions.question: Did Behrman know about the last leaf?
questions.answer: Yes, he painted it himself.

questions.question: What is a clause?
questions.answer: A group of words with a subject and a verb, part of a larger sentence.

questions.question: What is the setting of the story 'The Last Leaf'?
questions.answer: A poor artists' colony in New York.

questions.question: What is the significance of the title 'The Last Leaf'?
questions.answer: It symbolizes hope, life, and sacrifice. The painted leaf becomes the reason for Johnsy's recovery.

questions.question: What is pneumonia and why was it difficult to cure in the story's time?
questions.answer: Pneumonia is a serious lung infection. In the story's time, medical treatments were limited, and recovery often depended on the patient's will to live.

questions.question: How does Sue try to distract Johnsy from her negative thoughts?
questions.answer: She asks Johnsy to close her eyes while she works, tries to feed her broth, and talks about her own drawings to shift her focus.

questions.question: What is the condition of the ivy vine outside the window?
questions.answer: It is old, gnarled, and decayed at the roots. Most of its leaves have fallen due to autumn, leaving only bare skeleton branches.

questions.question: What does Johnsy mean when she says, 'When the last one falls, I must go, too'?
questions.answer: She has irrationally linked her own survival to the ivy vine, believing she will die when the last leaf falls.

questions.question: Why does Sue need Behrman as a model?
questions.answer: Sue is working on a drawing of an old man and needs a model. Behrman, being old and a fellow artist, fits the role.

questions.question: Describe Old Behrman's career as an artist.
questions.answer: He was a failed artist who had painted for forty years without success or money. He always talked about painting a masterpiece but never started it.

questions.question: How does Behrman earn a living?
questions.answer: He earns a little by serving as a model for young, struggling artists who cannot afford professional models.

questions.question: What was the weather like on the night Behrman painted the leaf?
questions.answer: It was a cold, stormy night with continuous rain mixed with snow and fierce winds.

questions.question: Why was Sue surprised to see the leaf still there the next morning?
questions.answer: Because the storm was so violent that night, she expected the last real leaf to have fallen.

questions.question: How does the sight of the 'last leaf' affect Johnsy initially?
questions.answer: Initially, it reinforces her belief that she will die when it falls, making her more resigned to her fate.

questions.question: What triggers the change in Johnsy's attitude?
questions.answer: Seeing the leaf bravely clinging to the vine through another storm makes her realize the sin of wanting to die and restores her will to live.

questions.question: What does Johnsy want to do after her change of heart?
questions.answer: She wants to sit up in bed, drink broth and milk, and expresses a wish to paint the Bay of Naples someday.

questions.question: How is Behrman found in his room?
questions.answer: The sweeper finds him lying helpless in wet clothes and shoes, having caught pneumonia.

questions.question: What clues in Behrman's room reveal what he did?
questions.answer: Scattered brushes and a palette with green and yellow paint mixed on it suggest he had been painting recently.

questions.question: Where is the real last ivy leaf after the storm?
questions.answer: It had fallen during the storm. The leaf Johnsy sees is the one painted by Behrman on the wall.

questions.question: Why didn't the painted leaf flutter in the wind?
questions.answer: Because it was painted on the brick wall, not a real leaf, so it remained still.

questions.question: What is ironic about Behrman's masterpiece?
questions.answer: The masterpiece he had dreamed of painting for years turned out to be a simple painted leaf that saved a life, not a grand painting.

questions.question: What lesson does the story teach about friendship?
questions.answer: True friendship involves care, support, and sometimes great personal sacrifice for the other's well-being.

questions.question: What does the story suggest about the power of the mind?
questions.answer: It suggests that a person's mental state and will to live are crucial for overcoming physical illness.

questions.question: How does the story define a 'sin' in Johnsy's context?
questions.answer: In the story, giving up on life and wishing to die is considered a sin against the gift of life and hope.

questions.question: What is the role of nature (the ivy vine) in the story?
questions.answer: Nature (the vine and its leaves) acts as a mirror for Johnsy's state of mind and becomes the focal point of her despair and subsequent hope.

questions.question: Why might the author have chosen an ivy vine specifically?
questions.answer: Ivy is often a symbol of fidelity, endurance, and eternal life. Its 'last leaf' represents clinging to life against odds.

questions.question: What character trait of Behrman is revealed at the end?
questions.answer: His hidden compassion, kindness, and willingness for self-sacrifice are revealed, contrasting with his gruff exterior.

questions.question: How does the story build suspense?
questions.answer: Suspense builds as the leaves fall, Johnsy's condition worsens, and the fate of the last leaf during the storm remains uncertain.

questions.question: What is the mood at the beginning of the story?
questions.answer: The mood is gloomy, hopeless, and filled with despair due to Johnsy's illness and her loss of will.

questions.question: How does the mood change at the end?
questions.answer: The mood becomes bittersweet—hopeful and uplifting due to Johnsy's recovery, but saddened by Behrman's death.

questions.question: What does the story imply about the value of art?
questions.answer: Art is shown to have immense power—not just as a commercial product, but as a means to inspire, give hope, and save lives.

questions.question: Explain the phrase 'struggling artists' as used in the story.
questions.answer: It refers to artists who are trying hard to make a living from their art but are poor and not yet successful.

questions.question: Why did Sue and Johnsy share a flat?
questions.answer: They were both struggling artists from different parts of the US who shared common interests and decided to live and work together to save costs.

questions.question: What is the narrative point of view of the story?
questions.answer: It is told from a third-person omniscient point of view, allowing the reader to know the thoughts and feelings of different characters.

questions.question: What role does the doctor play in the story?
questions.answer: The doctor diagnoses Johnsy and states the critical importance of her will to live, setting the central conflict into motion.

questions.question: How is the theme of sacrifice portrayed?
questions.answer: It is portrayed through Behrman's ultimate sacrifice—risking and losing his life to create the painting that gives Johnsy a reason to live.

questions.question: What is the 'climax' or turning point for Johnsy?
questions.answer: The moment she sees the leaf still clinging after the second night and decides she has been 'wicked' for wanting to die.

questions.question: What is the significance of Johnsy wanting to paint the Bay of Naples?
questions.answer: It symbolizes her return of hope, dreams for the future, and reconnection with her identity as an artist.

questions.question: How does the story show the contrast between youth and old age?
questions.answer: Johnsy (young) gives up on life easily, while Behrman (old) makes the ultimate sacrifice to give life to the young, showing unexpected strength and purpose in old age.

questions.question: Why is Behrman's action considered heroic?
questions.answer: He knowingly risked his life in terrible weather to paint the leaf, an act of pure selflessness that saved another person.

questions.question: What does the story tell us about false beliefs?
questions.answer: It warns that false beliefs can be dangerously powerful, but they can be overcome by acts of love and reality.

questions.question: How does the story's ending create an emotional impact?
questions.answer: The revelation that the leaf was a painting and that Behrman died creating it creates a powerful mix of sadness for his loss and joy for Johnsy's salvation.

questions.question: What is the main conflict in 'The Last Leaf'?
questions.answer: The main conflict is internal—Johnsy's loss of will to live versus the external efforts of Sue and Behrman to restore it.

questions.question: Why is the leaf described as hanging 'bravely'?
questions.answer: To personify it and align it with the theme of courage—it represents the brave fight for life against harsh conditions.

questions.question: What does Sue's profession tell us about her character?
questions.answer: It shows she is dedicated, hardworking, and caring, as she balances her own career struggles with nursing her friend.

questions.question: How does the author use foreshadowing?
questions.answer: Behrman's mention of painting a masterpiece and his strong reaction to Johnsy's fancy foreshadow his later action of painting the leaf.

questions.question: What is the lesson about judging people by appearances?
questions.answer: Behrman appeared to be a gruff, failed old man, but inside he was a hero capable of great kindness and sacrifice.

questions.question: How does the story connect art and life?
questions.answer: Art (the painted leaf) directly intervenes in and saves a life, showing that art is not separate from life but can be a vital part of it.

questions.question: What might be the 'warming up' activity's purpose in this chapter?
questions.answer: To get students thinking about illness, recovery, and mental attitude, which are central themes of the story they are about to read.

questions.question: In the context of the story, what does 'lo' mean?
questions.answer: It is an archaic exclamation meaning 'look!' or 'see!', used to draw attention to something surprising.

questions.question: What does Johnsy's counting of the leaves symbolize?
questions.answer: It symbolizes her countdown to death, her obsession with her own demise, and her detachment from the living world.

questions.question: Why is 'The Last Leaf' considered a classic short story?
questions.answer: Because of its timeless themes of hope and sacrifice, its well-crafted plot twist, and its ability to evoke deep emotion in readers.
